This statement does not necessarily imply that if Q (Mark bought the blue shirt), then P (Lisa bought the red shirt). 

In logic, this is known as the "converse error." The original statement only guarantees that if P is true (Lisa bought the red shirt), then Q is true (Mark bought the blue shirt). It does not guarantee that if Q is true, then P is true.
